thread.title: Corals don’t need our help
thread.title_full: Corals don’t need our help - The Washington Post

author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Corals don’t need our help
text:
An aerial photo of Kaneohe Bay with Coconut Island, the site of the Hawaii Institute of Marine Biology, in the foreground. The light patches in the water are patch reefs, including Keyhole Reef at the extreme right of the image. (Courtesy of Ruth Gates) October 22 at 5:54 PM Regarding the Oct. 20 Health & Science article “ Creating corals that can survive climate change ”:
While it is true that marine corals are under some stress at present, efforts to enhance their survival by selective breeding seem unnecessary; nature, i.e., evolution, has done the job.
Corals of various types have been around for a half-billion years (the Cambrian Period ) and became overwhelmingly abundant in the Ordovician Period (about 450 million years ago). Apart from a brief hiatus at the Permian-Triassic Extinction (roughly a quarter-billion years ago), from which they recovered handily, corals have survived the many extreme environmental swings throughout Earth’s history without our assistance.
Priestley Toulmin , Alexandria
